title: 1 Timothy Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Timothy chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Timothy Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Timothy Chapter 6.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 6:1, how should servants regard their masters?
questions.correctAnswer: Worthy of all honour
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:1 instructs servants to count their masters worthy of all honour so that God's name and doctrine are not blasphemed.

questions.question: In 1 Timothy 6:2, how should servants treat their believing masters?
questions.correctAnswer: Do them service
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:2 teaches that servants with believing masters should do them service because they are faithful and beloved.

questions.question: What does 1 Timothy 6:3 say about those who teach otherwise than the doctrine of godliness?
options: They know nothing and are proud
questions.correctAnswer: They know nothing and are proud
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:3-4 describes such people as proud and knowing nothing, engaging in strife and questions.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 6:6, what is considered great gain?
questions.correctAnswer: Godliness with contentment
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:6 states that godliness combined with contentment is great gain.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Timothy 6:7 says that we can carry possessions with us when we leave this world.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:7 clearly states that we brought nothing into this world, and certainly can carry nothing out.

questions.question: What does 1 Timothy 6:9 warn those who desire to be rich will fall into?
questions.correctAnswer: Temptation and a snare
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:9 warns that those who want to be rich fall into temptation and a snare with many harmful desires.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 6:10, what is the root of all evil?
questions.correctAnswer: The love of money
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:10 states that the love of money is the root of all evil.

questions.question: In 1 Timothy 6:11, which of the following is NOT listed as a characteristic to follow?
questions.correctAnswer: Wealth
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:11 lists righteousness, godliness, faith, love, patience, and meekness, but not wealth.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Timothy 6:12: 'Fight the good fight of faith, lay hold on ______ life.'
questions.correctAnswer: eternal
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:12 instructs to lay hold on eternal life.

questions.question: Who witnessed a good confession before Pontius Pilate according to 1 Timothy 6:13?
questions.correctAnswer: Christ Jesus
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:13 mentions Christ Jesus as the one who witnessed a good confession before Pontius Pilate.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 6:15, who is described as the King of kings and Lord of lords?
questions.correctAnswer: The blessed and only Potentate
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:15 describes the Lord Jesus Christ as the blessed and only Potentate, King of kings and Lord of lords.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Timothy 6:16 says that no man has seen or can see God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:16 states that no man has seen or can see God who only has immortality.

questions.question: What advice does 1 Timothy 6:17 give to those who are rich in this world?
options: Be humble and trust in God
questions.correctAnswer: Be humble and trust in God
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:17 charges the rich not to be highminded or trust in uncertain riches but in the living God.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 6:18, what should the rich be ready to do?
questions.correctAnswer: Distribute and communicate
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:18 instructs the rich to be ready to distribute and willing to communicate.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Timothy 6:20 warns Timothy to avoid profane and vain babblings and oppositions of falsely called science.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:20 explicitly warns Timothy to keep his trust by avoiding profane babblings and false science.

medium.title: 1 Timothy Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Timothy Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Timothy 6 teach us about honoring authority in the workplace?
options: Count your masters worthy of all honor to avoid blasphemy
Serve only if the master is kind and generous
Ignore your masters if they are unbelievers
Only obey masters when it benefits you
questions.correctAnswer: Count your masters worthy of all honor to avoid blasphemy
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:1 instructs servants to honor their masters so that God's name and doctrine are not blasphemed. This teaches respect and integrity in work relationships regardless of circumstances.

questions.question: What attitude should servants have toward believing masters according to 1 Timothy 6?
options: Do not despise them, but serve them because they are brethren
Avoid serving them to maintain independence
Serve them only out of obligation
questions.correctAnswer: Do not despise them, but serve them because they are brethren
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:2 encourages servants to respect believing masters as fellow believers and serve them faithfully, emphasizing unity and mutual respect among Christians.

questions.question: What does 1 Timothy 6 warn about those who teach false doctrines?
options: They are proud and cause strife and envy
They are humble and teach peace
They promote unity in the church
questions.correctAnswer: They are proud and cause strife and envy
questions.explanation: Verses 3-5 describe false teachers as proud, ignorant, causing disputes, envy, and promoting corrupt ideas like gain being godliness, which believers are to avoid.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 6, what is considered 'great gain'?
questions.correctAnswer: Godliness with contentment
questions.explanation: Verse 6 teaches that combining godly living with contentment is truly profitable, contrasting with the pursuit of riches which leads to troubles.

questions.question: What does 1 Timothy 6:7-8 teach about material possessions?
options: We brought nothing into the world and should be content with food and clothing
We should accumulate as much as possible
We can take riches with us after death
questions.correctAnswer: We brought nothing into the world and should be content with food and clothing
questions.explanation: These verses remind believers of the transient nature of possessions and call for contentment with basic needs, reinforcing humility and trust in God.

questions.question: What warning does 1 Timothy 6 give about the desire to be rich?
options: It leads to temptation, snares, and ruin
It is a sign of God's blessing
It is a necessary goal for Christians
questions.correctAnswer: It leads to temptation, snares, and ruin
questions.explanation: Verse 9 warns that pursuing wealth can cause people to fall into harmful desires and destruction, highlighting the spiritual dangers of materialism.

questions.question: What is described as the root of all evil in 1 Timothy 6?
questions.correctAnswer: The love of money
questions.explanation: Verse 10 clearly states that the love of money is the root of all evil, leading some away from faith and causing many sorrows.

questions.question: What virtues does 1 Timothy 6:11 encourage believers to pursue?
options: Righteousness, godliness, faith, love, patience, meekness
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness, godliness, faith, love, patience, meekness
questions.explanation: Verse 11 urges believers to flee harmful desires and instead pursue godly virtues that characterize a faithful Christian life.

questions.question: What does Paul mean by 'fight the good fight of faith' in 1 Timothy 6:12?
options: Persevere in faith to obtain eternal life
questions.correctAnswer: Persevere in faith to obtain eternal life
questions.explanation: Verse 12 encourages believers to actively persevere in their faith journey, holding firmly to the hope of eternal life to which they are called.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 6, what is the nature of God who calls believers to faith?
options: The only immortal and eternal King of kings
A god dependent on human worship
questions.correctAnswer: The only immortal and eternal King of kings
questions.explanation: Verses 15-16 describe God as the blessed, only Potentate who alone has immortality and dwells in unapproachable light, deserving everlasting honor.

questions.question: What advice does 1 Timothy 6 give to those who are rich in this world?
options: Do not be arrogant or put trust in wealth but in God
Trust in their money for security
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be arrogant or put trust in wealth but in God
questions.explanation: Verse 17 instructs the wealthy not to be proud or trust uncertain riches but to trust in the living God who richly provides all things for enjoyment.

questions.question: How should rich believers behave according to 1 Timothy 6?
options: Be rich in good works, generous and ready to share
Avoid helping others to keep wealth secure
Judge others by their financial status
questions.correctAnswer: Be rich in good works, generous and ready to share
questions.explanation: Verses 18-19 teach that rich believers should do good, be generous, and prepare a good foundation for eternal life through their good deeds.

questions.question: What is Timothy instructed to guard in 1 Timothy 6:20?
options: The faith entrusted to him, avoiding false knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: The faith entrusted to him, avoiding false knowledge
questions.explanation: Verse 20 charges Timothy to protect the faith given to him and avoid profane and vain babblings and false teachings masquerading as knowledge.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Timothy 6, contentment with food and clothing is sufficient for a believer's great gain.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 6-8 and 1 Timothy 6:8 specifically state that godliness with contentment, including basic needs like food and clothing, is great gain for believers.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Timothy 6 teaches that the love of money is a minor issue to be balanced with faith.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 10 clearly states that the love of money is the root of all evil and has caused many to stray from the faith and suffer sorrow, indicating it is a serious spiritual danger.

hard.title: 1 Timothy Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Timothy Chapter 6.

questions.question: In 1 Timothy 6:6, the phrase 'godliness with contentment' is described as what?
questions.correctAnswer: Great gain
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:6 states that 'godliness with contentment is great gain,' emphasizing the spiritual and practical value of a godly life coupled with satisfaction.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 6:10, what is identified as the root of all evil?
questions.correctAnswer: The love of money
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states that 'the love of money is the root of all evil,' highlighting the dangers of covetousness in Christian ethics.

questions.question: What charge is given to Timothy in the sight of God and Christ Jesus in 1 Timothy 6:13?
options: To keep the commandment without spot and unrebukeable
To preach to the Gentiles only
To avoid all contact with unbelievers
To build a church in Ephesus
questions.correctAnswer: To keep the commandment without spot and unrebukeable
questions.explanation: The verse charges Timothy to maintain purity and integrity in keeping the commandment until the Lord's appearing.

questions.question: In the cultural context of 1 Timothy 6:1-2, why are servants instructed to honor their masters?
options: So that the name of God and His doctrine be not blasphemed
To gain wealth and social status
To avoid punishment from the government
questions.correctAnswer: So that the name of God and His doctrine be not blasphemed
questions.explanation: Verse 1 explains that servants must honor their masters to uphold the reputation of God's name and doctrine among outsiders, reflecting early Christian social ethics.

questions.question: What attitude toward riches does 1 Timothy 6:17 recommend to those who are rich in this world?
options: Not to be highminded nor trust in uncertain riches, but in the living God
To invest all wealth in the temple treasury
To avoid all contact with poor people
To seek public recognition for their wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Not to be highminded nor trust in uncertain riches, but in the living God
questions.explanation: The verse instructs the wealthy to avoid arrogance and to place their trust in God, who provides all things richly for enjoyment.

questions.question: 1 Timothy 6:20 warns Timothy to avoid what type of teachings?
options: Profane and vain babblings, and oppositions of science falsely so called
questions.correctAnswer: Profane and vain babblings, and oppositions of science falsely so called
questions.explanation: This verse cautions Timothy to steer clear of empty talk and false knowledge that distort the Christian faith.

questions.question: Which of the following virtues is NOT listed in 1 Timothy 6:11 as something to follow after?
questions.correctAnswer: Wealth
questions.explanation: Verse 11 lists righteousness, godliness, faith, love, patience, and meekness, but not wealth, emphasizing spiritual qualities over material gain.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Timothy 6:7, it is certain that we can carry possessions with us after death.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states 'we brought nothing into this world, and it is certain we can carry nothing out,' denying the possibility of taking possessions beyond death.

questions.question: How does 1 Timothy 6:15 describe the Lord Jesus Christ in relation to earthly rulers?
options: As the blessed and only Potentate, King of kings, and Lord of lords
As a humble servant among kings
As a prophet equal to the rulers
As a judge only for the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: As the blessed and only Potentate, King of kings, and Lord of lords
questions.explanation: The verse highlights Christ’s supreme sovereignty above all earthly rulers, a title affirming His divine authority.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'which before Pontius Pilate witnessed a good confession' in 1 Timothy 6:13?
options: It situates Christ’s testimony historically during His trial
It is a metaphor for spiritual warfare
It refers to Timothy’s confession before the church
questions.correctAnswer: It situates Christ’s testimony historically during His trial
questions.explanation: This phrase anchors Christ’s witness in a real historical event, lending authority to Timothy’s charge.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 6:9, what do those who desire to be rich fall into?
options: Temptation and a snare, and into many foolish and hurtful lusts
questions.correctAnswer: Temptation and a snare, and into many foolish and hurtful lusts
questions.explanation: The verse warns that the desire for riches leads to temptation and destructive desires, resulting in ruin.

questions.question: What is the relationship between godliness and contentment as portrayed in 1 Timothy 6:6-8?
options: Godliness combined with contentment is great gain, as we brought nothing into the world and should be content with food and raiment
Godliness requires constant striving for wealth and possessions
Only the wealthy can be truly godly
questions.correctAnswer: Godliness combined with contentment is great gain, as we brought nothing into the world and should be content with food and raiment
questions.explanation: These verses teach that spiritual devotion accompanied by satisfaction with basic needs is valuable, reflecting humility and trust in God.

questions.question: Which of the following best captures the literary device used in 1 Timothy 6:10 with 'the love of money is the root of all evil'?
options: Hyperbole emphasizing the danger of greed
Simile illustrating the comparison of money to a root
Metaphor describing money as a source of life
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole emphasizing the danger of greed
questions.explanation: The statement is a strong, hyperbolic warning against covetousness, highlighting its pervasive destructive influence.

questions.question: How does 1 Timothy 6:2 illustrate early Christian views on social hierarchy and brotherhood?
options: Believing servants should not despise believing masters because they are brethren
Masters and servants are completely separate with no spiritual connection
questions.correctAnswer: Believing servants should not despise believing masters because they are brethren
questions.explanation: This verse reflects the early Christian ethic that faith creates spiritual brotherhood transcending social status.

questions.question: True or False: In 1 Timothy 6:19, laying up a good foundation in good works is linked to the hope of eternal life.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse directly connects generous good works with establishing a foundation to grasp eternal life, emphasizing practical faith.

theological.title: 1 Timothy Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Timothy Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 6, what attitude should servants have toward their masters to prevent blasphemy of God's name and doctrine?
options: Count their masters worthy of all honour
Seek to be free from servitude
questions.correctAnswer: Count their masters worthy of all honour
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:1 instructs servants to regard their masters as worthy of all honour so that God's name and doctrine are not blasphemed. This reflects the biblical principle of submission to authority found also in Romans 13:1-7 and Ephesians 6:5-8, emphasizing order and respect within Christian conduct.

questions.question: What is the primary reason given for serving believing masters according to 1 Timothy 6:2?
options: Because they are brethren and faithful
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are brethren and faithful
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:2 teaches that servants should not despise believing masters because they are brethren but rather serve them because they are faithful and beloved. This highlights the unity of the body of Christ as seen also in Galatians 3:28 and Hebrews 13:17.

questions.question: What characterizes a person who teaches contrary to godly doctrine, according to 1 Timothy 6:3-4?
options: Proud and ignorant, focusing on disputes and strife
questions.correctAnswer: Proud and ignorant, focusing on disputes and strife
questions.explanation: Verses 3 and 4 describe such a person as proud, knowing nothing, and obsessed with arguments that produce envy and strife. This aligns with warnings in Titus 3:9 and 2 Timothy 2:23-25 about foolish controversies and quarrels.

questions.question: What is the instruction regarding men who think that gain is godliness in 1 Timothy 6?
questions.correctAnswer: Withdraw yourself from them
questions.explanation: 1 Timothy 6:5 warns that those who see gain as godliness are of corrupt minds and destitute of truth, and Paul commands withdrawal from such individuals. This principle is echoed in 2 Timothy 3:5 and Romans 16:17 regarding avoiding divisive and false teachers.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 6:6, what is considered 'great gain'?
questions.correctAnswer: Godliness with contentment
questions.explanation: Verse 6 clearly states that godliness combined with contentment is great gain, emphasizing spiritual riches over material wealth. This aligns with Proverbs 15:16, Hebrews 13:5, and Matthew 6:19-21 which teach contentment and the value of godliness.

questions.question: What does 1 Timothy 6:7 teach about our possessions in this world?
options: We brought nothing in and can carry nothing out
We should accumulate as much as possible
questions.correctAnswer: We brought nothing in and can carry nothing out
questions.explanation: Verse 7 reinforces the transient nature of material possessions, reminding believers that earthly goods are temporary. This echoes Ecclesiastes 5:15 and Job 1:21, underscoring the futility of trusting in wealth.

questions.question: What is the warning given in 1 Timothy 6:9 about those who desire to be rich?
options: They fall into temptation, snare, and foolish lusts
questions.correctAnswer: They fall into temptation, snare, and foolish lusts
questions.explanation: Verse 9 warns that the desire for riches leads to temptation and destructive desires. This is consistent with Jesus' warning in Matthew 13:22 and James 1:14-15 about the dangers of covetousness.

questions.question: What is described as the 'root of all evil' in 1 Timothy 6:10?
questions.correctAnswer: The love of money
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states the love of money is the root of all evil, leading some to stray from the faith. This parallels teachings in Matthew 6:24 and Hebrews 13:5 about the dangers of loving money over God.

questions.question: Which virtues does 1 Timothy 6:11 exhort the man of God to pursue?
options: Righteousness, godliness, faith, love, patience, meekness
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness, godliness, faith, love, patience, meekness
questions.explanation: Verse 11 commands pursuit of these Christlike virtues, reflecting the fruit of the Spirit in Galatians 5:22-23 and the moral exhortations in 2 Peter 1:5-7.

questions.question: What is the 'good fight of faith' that believers are called to fight according to 1 Timothy 6:12?
options: The struggle to hold onto eternal life
questions.correctAnswer: The struggle to hold onto eternal life
questions.explanation: Verse 12 encourages believers to fight the good fight of faith and grasp eternal life, highlighting perseverance in faith as seen also in 2 Timothy 4:7 and Hebrews 12:1-2.

questions.question: Who is described as the 'blessed and only Potentate, the King of kings, and Lord of lords' in 1 Timothy 6:15?
questions.correctAnswer: Our Lord Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Verse 15 identifies Jesus Christ as the supreme sovereign, a title affirming His divine kingship consistent with Revelation 19:16 and Isaiah 44:6.

questions.question: What attribute of God is emphasized in 1 Timothy 6:16?
options: Immortality and dwelling in unapproachable light
questions.correctAnswer: Immortality and dwelling in unapproachable light
questions.explanation: Verse 16 highlights God's unique immortality and holiness, dwelling in unapproachable light, a theme echoed in Exodus 33:20 and 1 Timothy 1:17.

questions.question: What charge is given to the rich in this world according to 1 Timothy 6:17?
options: Do not be haughty or trust in uncertain riches but in God
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be haughty or trust in uncertain riches but in God
questions.explanation: Verse 17 instructs the wealthy to avoid pride and false security in riches, trusting instead in God who richly provides. This mirrors Proverbs 11:28 and Luke 12:15 teachings.

questions.question: According to 1 Timothy 6:18, what are the rich encouraged to do with their wealth?
options: Do good, be rich in good works, ready to distribute
questions.correctAnswer: Do good, be rich in good works, ready to distribute
questions.explanation: Verse 18 urges the rich to be generous and charitable, reflecting biblical calls to stewardship and generosity found in Acts 20:35 and 2 Corinthians 9:6-7.

questions.question: What is Timothy specifically instructed to guard according to 1 Timothy 6:20?
options: The faith entrusted to him, avoiding profane babblings and false science
questions.correctAnswer: The faith entrusted to him, avoiding profane babblings and false science
questions.explanation: Verse 20 directs Timothy to guard the gospel deposit and avoid heretical and vain arguments, consistent with Paul's warnings in 2 Timothy 1:13-14 and Jude 3.
